properties.How to get there: The entrance to the main car park is 1km down Kennedys Bush Road, Halswell - take the 100 bus and get off on Glovers Road
properties.Features: From the Findlay car park, turn right onto the track that runs along the edge of the picnic area to find plenty of log rounds and a big carved log for climbing and jumping. At the back of the picnic area there's a great big hill slope for rolling and running down and if you follow the vehicle track, there's plenty of spots for water and mud play by the wetland plantings - including stepping stones across the creek. Don't forget your gumboots!

properties.How to get there: The entrance to the main car park is 1km down Kennedys Bush Road, Halswell - take the 100 bus and get off on Glovers Road
properties.Features: From the main car park, take the path over the wooden bridge to find lots of meandering paths through the plantings to explore. The park rangers have placed logs in the grass - have a rummage and dig around to find insects and maybe even a lizard! The pond in the centre is full of wetland birds and tuna/eel - see what you can spot!

properties.How to get there: End of Rocking Horse Road, Southshore - take the number 60 bus to Southshore at the end of the line
properties.Features: Enjoy winding tracks for running and exploring, long grass for hiding and easy beach access for water play and digging in the sand. You can also head to the Ihutai Avon Heathcote Estuary to spot mud-crabs and wading birds - don't forget your binoculars!

properties.How to get there: Beside Greenaway Park, Greenaway Street, Halswell – take the Orange bus to Greenaway Park.
properties.Features: This purpose built nature play reserve has climbing logs, wooden beams to balance on, log rounds to jump on and lots of tall grass and plantings to explore and hide among!

properties.How to get there: Worsleys Road, Cashmere - take the 145 bus to Cashmere Road near Marvin Road
properties.Features: This reserve features a beautiful stream for splashing, new plantings to explore, and birds to watch. Head down in autumn to jump in the crisy leaves of the huge heritage oak tree!

properties.How to get there: Worsleys Road, Cashmere - take the 145 bus to Cashmere Road near Marvin Road
properties.Features: An easy sealed path follows the river in this reserve. Explore new plantings, splash in the stream and watch birds here.

properties.How to get there: Worsleys Road, Cashmere - take the 145 bus to Woodside Common near Ravensdale Rise
properties.Features: This reserve is packed with winding paths to explore, birds to watch and a beautiful stream to splash in.

properties.How to get there: Hillsborough Terrace, Hillsborough - take the 145 bus to Hillsborough Terrace
properties.Features: From the car park, take the right fork up through the trees on Dry Ridge Track to reach a cave overhang. It's about a ten minute walk uphill for little legs. The park also has large areas of tussock planting which is great fun for swishing through!

properties.How to get there: Ferrymead Park Drive, Ferrymead - take the 535 bus to Bridle Path Road
properties.Features: Ferrymead is an exciting spot. The park ponds have lots of ducks and wetland birds to see as well as insects hanging out on wetland plants like harakeke/flax and rushes. There is also a pump track dirt circuit for biking or running around near the Sport's Pavilion.

properties.How to get there: Located on the corner of Stanmore and River Roads
properties.Features: This pop up has balance beams, log leap, grass maze, rolling slopes and fruit trees.

properties.How to get there: 251 River Road, Richmond. Closest road access is Evelyn Couzins Ave.
properties.Features: Enjoy mushroom-themed play, a playhouse and mud kitchen, tunnels and carvings.

properties.How to get there: Corner of Medway Street and Woodchester Ave
properties.Features: Enjoy a pump track for riding or running, a child-designed tree house playground and picnic tables. Photo credit to Hayley Guglietta.

properties.How to get there: Access the space via Cowlishaw Street
properties.Features: Climb the fallen tree, hunt for insects and cehck out the school vege gardens and chickens.

properties.How to get there: Access of Keyes Road
properties.Features: Enjoy paths, net and rope climbs, climbing logs, slides and a disabled swing in this community created playground. Find out more at https://www.facebook.com/GuardiansofRawhiti.

properties.How to get there: The nature playground runs along the back of the basketball court and playground, access off Riverlaw Terrace.
properties.Features: Hop across logs, build your own hut and expore the garden! Photo credit to Celia Hogan.

properties.How to get there: 60 Alderson Terrace, Hillsborough
properties.Features: Balance on log beams, cross the bridge, explore the tall weedy areas and roll down the slopes!

properties.How to get there: Access off Belair Close Reserve, Burwood
properties.Features: This soon to be open nature playground is being developed by Green Lab for Avon-Ōtākaro Forest Park. It will feature logs for climbing, native plants to expore and much more.

properties.How to get there: Fairy Village is located along Apple Road in Bottle Lake Forest. It is not far from the main car park of Waitikiri Drive.
properties.Features: This magical village is home to hundreds of fairy homes built by families from all over the city. All are welcome to visit and put up their own special fairy houses or doors.

properties.How to get there: Located in Champagne Reserve, off Sir John Mckenzie Drive.
properties.Features: This beautiful new playground includes timber logs, boulder play, swings, digger, mound with slide, tunnel, climbing logs and picnic table. Attached to the playground is a sensory garden surrounded by a ring of Canterbury native trees. Photo credit to Glasson Huxtable Landscape Architects, https://www.ghla.co.nz/yaldhurst-nature-playground.

properties.How to get there: Located a short walk into the Garden of Tāne. Access off Rue Jolie/Aylmers Valley Road.
properties.Features: A beautiful play area with logs and rounds, a timber walkway, a macrocarpa hut and more all located in a winding bush network.

properties.How to get there: Dedicated car parking is available off Hussey and Styx Mill Roads.
properties.Features: Go bird watching around the lake and then follow the path across a number of bridges to the forest covered winding paths of the Hussey View Walkway.

properties.How to get there: Off Heyders Road in Spencerville
properties.Features: A play paradise, Spencer Park has both traditional playgrounds and plenty of nature to explore. With big fields to run around, a wetland boardwalk to spot wildlife from and the beach nearby for digging in the sand and water play, plan for a whole day!

properties.How to get there: Located over the road from Spencer Park, there is dedicated car parking off Heyders Road to the left.
properties.Features: Dig for critters and fungi under logs, check out the birds and pigs in the animal area and hop on log rounds.
